awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  RAPID:  Capturing initial eco-evolutionary dynamics of a novel chemical invader
awd_abstract_narration:
Strong human-mediated selection can cause rapid evolution in traits that alter ecological dynamics. Such eco-evolutionary processes may also lead to unpredictable changes in biological systems. The application of herbicides, for example, causes a range of responses in plants such as death, stunted growth, or the alteration of flowering times of survivors. Plant populations exposed to herbicide often evolve resistance. It is not known if these herbicide-induced changes can affect other key ecological components of a community such as plant-pollinator interactions. This research will examine the potential for cascading eco-evolutionary effects of herbicide application within crop associated weed communities. The researchers will take advantage of the impending widespread application of the novel herbicide dicamba. The work is specifically designed to capture the initial dynamics of dicamba's use in agriculture. This research will focus on the crop-associated weed community and its interaction with insect pollinators. Ultimately, this project has broad implications for the health and resilience of agricultural systems following human-mediated influences. The evolution of these wild species may have substantial effects on agricultural sustainability, the economics of food production, and human health.

The eco-evolutionary forces studied here are likely to create evolutionary responses that lead to significant ecological change. An understanding of these phenomena is incomplete, however, as few natural systems have so far been examined for direct links between evolving traits and ecological impacts. Moreover, the initial dynamics in such systems are rarely captured. The proposed research takes advantage of the upcoming widespread application of a new herbicide to study its cascading effects on ecological and evolutionary processes in crop-associated weed communities, including important natural pollinators. This work will test four hypotheses concerning the initial ecological and evolutionary processes. Ecological processes to be studied include the role of phenotypic plasticity in invasion dynamics and changes in pollinator abundances and diversity. Evolutionary processes include plant species losses and reductions in genetic diversity. The work will use a combination of field studies and genetic analyses to capture the initial processes in a dynamic that is expected to proceed very rapidly. This research will provide key insight into a critical stage of eco-evolutionary processes that occur at the agro-ecological interface.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A major outcome of this research was an assessment of weed communities at the initial stages of dicamba use in agroecosystems and sampling seeds of species for later use. Specifically, we performed vegetation surveys and sampled replicate seeds of weeds found in agricultural crops in central TN and western KY, two areas that have recently seen widespread adoption of dicamba tolerant soy as well as corn fields. We identified weed species found at the edge or within the fields and collected data on both presence and abundance of each species to record base-line data on species present at the early adoption stage of dicamba-tolerant crops. We sampled seeds from 5-50 maternal lines per species to form the basis of future work on the evolution of dicamba tolerance and resistance traits.

We examined initial responses of 25 species of herbaceous plants spanning 15 families to dicamba drift in a large greenhouse experiment. We determined if the weed species varied in resistance or tolerance to dicamba drift, whether dicamba drift alters floral traits important for plant-pollinator interactions, specifically the probability of flowering, date of first flower, and flower size, and whether dicamba exposure leads to community-level changes in the co-flowering communities that could lead altered plant-plant or plant-pollinator interactions. We found that species varied in resistance and tolerance to dicamba drift: some species were negatively impacted while others showed overcompensatory responses. Species also differed in the way they deployed flowers over time following drift exposure. Drift reduced the degree and intensity of flowering overlap among species, altered the composition of groups of species that were more likely to coflower with each other than with others, and shifted species roles (e.g., from dominant to inferior floral producers and vice versa).

We likewise conducted a dicamba drift field experiment involving 11 species in 10 plots replicated at three locations (TN, PA and MI) to assess the interactive effects of species, climate and dicamba drift on plant and pollinator responses. We specifically examined the potential for plant damage, growth, and flowering changes in response to dicamba drift along with the potential for alterations in plant-pollinator interactions to determine if novel herbicide exposure alters important species interactions. We replicated this experiment twice. We found that dicamba exposure affected weed species differently and that responses of species were often location (MI/PA/TN) dependent. All species showed significant leaf damage, but a few species showed little change in terms of growth (Oxalis stricta, Cardiospermum halicacabum, Lepidium virginicum) or flowering phenology (Taraxacum officinale, Oxalis stricta, Plantago lanceolata). Alternatively, another handful of species (Ipomoea hederacea, Ipomoea lacunosa, Sida spinosa, and Amaranthus palmeri) showed reduced growth after dicamba application compared to the control plants and/or evidence of damage and likewise generally flowered later or less. We further observed that the abundance of pollinators and other plant visitors (e.g. ants) were significantly reduced in plots that had experienced dicamba drift and that three weed species experienced lower visitation by pollinators or generalist insect visitors. A survey of pollinating insects and generalist plant visitors showed significantly reduced abundance of these organisms in plots that had experienced dicamba drift. Structural equation modeling indicated that in the presence of dicamba drift, both the approach and visitation rates of pollinators and generalist plant visitors were directly influenced by the number of flowers plants produced whereas early growth directly and indirectly influenced the number of flowers. Early growth also directly influenced pollinator approach rates. The project provided valuable educational and training opportunities for one Masters student, three PhD students, two technicians, one post-baccalaureate student as well as numerous undergraduate researchers, and additionally contributed to the career development of two evolutionary ecologists.
